G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting time order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a determination that modification is in the best interests of the minor children.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Massachusetts Courts have consistently emphasized that the welfare and best interests of the children are the paramount consideration in custody and visitation determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly states that the governing standard in custody and removal questions is the best interests or welfare of the child, and treats that consideration as paramount over parents’ competing interests. In construing the removal statute and articulating the “real advantage” test, the court expressly grounds its analysis in the principle that removal must be in the child’s best interests and that those best interests remain the central, overriding concern. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts emphasize the children’s welfare as the paramount consideration in custody and visitation determinations.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘[a] minor child… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Purdy v. Cole, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 517 (19.raw_text: Purdy v. Cole, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 517 (1988)
Purdy v. Cole, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 517 (19.proposition: The Massachusetts Courts have consistently emphasized that the welfare and best interests of the children are the paramount consideration in custody and visitation determinations.
Purdy v. Cole, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 517 (19.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about exclusion of a late-disclosed alibi witness, jury instructions, and sufficiency of an indictment. It does not involve custody, visitation, or any discussion of the welfare or best interests of children. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the principle that Massachusetts courts emphasize the best interests of the child in custody and visitation matters.
Purdy v. Cole, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 517 (19.relevant_excerpt: Such limits as bear on the discretion of a trial judge to bar an alibi witness whom the defense has not timely identified were recently discussed in Taylor v. Illinois, 484 U.S. 400 (1988). In all criminal prosecutions, the Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution provides, “the accused shall enjoy the right ... to have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his favor. ...” Right to process carries with it the necessary implication that the witness brought to court will be heard and, indeed, the right of an accused to present witnesses in his defense is a fundamental element of the adversary system.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Here, the Defendant’s new employment schedule directly affects his ability to provide consistent and appropriate care during his scheduled parenting time.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses each parent’s work hours and how those schedules affect the amount of time the child spends in day care and with each parent, but it does not address a parent’s *new* or changed employment schedule, nor does it frame work-schedule impacts in terms of an inability to provide consistent or appropriate care during that parent’s scheduled parenting time. Instead, the court uses comparative work flexibility and day care use as part of a broader best-interests analysis. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition about a defendant’s new schedule directly impairing his ability to care for the child during his time.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “…the father works long hours, often involving overtime, resulting in Kali’s spending most of her time during the week in day care; that the mother has more flexible hours and is able to spend more time with Kali during the weekdays…Kali is to spend school weekdays with her mother because her mother’s schedule was sufficiently flexible to ensure that Kali’s needs during those periods will be attended to…we are satisfied here that the judge considered Kali’s respective day care arrangements and the work schedules of her parents in the context of balancing many factors….”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts law also prioritizes the fitness of the custodial parent and the stability of the home environment when determining custody and parenting time.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is framed around determining custody based on the child’s best interests, and it clearly requires attention to the parent’s fitness—here, especially the impact of the father’s domestic violence on his parenting ability—and to the child’s need for a safe, non-violent home. While the case emphasizes domestic violence more than general "stability of the home" language, its remand instruction that courts make explicit findings on how violence affects the child and the appropriateness of the custody arrangement reflects a focus on custodial fitness and the stability/safety of the child’s home environment.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’... The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. ... Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking."

B.B. v. B.J., 73 Mass. App. Ct. 653 (200.raw_text: B.B. v. B.J., 73 Mass. App. Ct. 653 (2009)
B.B. v. B.J., 73 Mass. App. Ct. 653 (200.proposition: Massachusetts law also prioritizes the fitness of the custodial parent and the stability of the home environment when determining custody and parenting time.
B.B. v. B.J., 73 Mass. App. Ct. 653 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns expungement versus sealing of an erroneously issued criminal complaint and the court’s inherent authority to order expungement. It does not address child custody, parenting time, parental fitness, or stability of the home environment. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for how Massachusetts law prioritizes custodial parent fitness and home stability in custody determinations.
B.B. v. B.J., 73 Mass. App. Ct. 653 (200.relevant_excerpt: “We are asked by the commissioner of probation to vacate an order of a Boston Municipal Court judge expunging the defendant’s record, and to limit the defendant’s remedy to the scheme in the sealing statute, G. L. c. 276, § 100C, second par. For reasons which follow, we affirm the judge’s expungement order.”

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: A material change in work hours or inability to adhere to a parenting schedule justifies modifying the custody order.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody, visitation, and removal, but not in terms of changed work hours or inability to follow an existing parenting schedule. The custody and visitation modification here is based on domestic violence, coercive control, and the child’s best interests, including a one-year suspension of all contact, not on a parent’s work schedule changing. Therefore, the case does not provide authority for the proposition that a material change in work hours or inability to adhere to a parenting schedule justifies modifying custody.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, the judge made findings that the father was domineering in his relations with the mother and child… The judge’s decision to suspend visitation for one year is also supported by his extensive findings that over the course of their relationship, the father had engaged in physical, emotional, and financial abuse of the mother, and, in his interactions with the child, had damaged the mother’s relationship with the child… the decision to suspend the father’s visitation rights with the child was based on the exercise of a sound discretion.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: The Defendant’s need to rely on a roommate for childcare further threatens the children’s best interests when such individuals have not been approved by this Court or adequately vetted.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address court approval or vetting of roommates or other third-party childcare providers. Its analysis centers on whether splitting identical twin siblings between parents serves their best interests and criticizes the judge’s overreliance on the children’s stated preferences. There is no discussion of a parent’s reliance on a roommate for childcare or any requirement that such individuals be vetted or approved by the court, so it cannot be cited as authority for that proposition.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: "When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children. . . . The list of factors within the judge’s purview in child custody matters includes a presumption generally favoring the placement of siblings under one roof. . . . The list also allows the judge to consider the expressions of a preference by a child in a custody dispute."
